question: How long is one complete rotation of Earth on its axis, and what does it cause?

content.source_1: Earth’s axial rotation causes the alternation of daylight and darkness at a given location on the planet.
content.source_2: The mean solar day—the average interval from one local solar noon to the next—is defined as 24 hours, and civil clocks are calibrated to this 24-hour day.
content.source_3: As Earth orbits the Sun, it advances about 1 degree along its orbit each day, so to bring the Sun back to the same apparent sky position, Earth must rotate slightly more than 360 degrees.
content.source_4: A full 360-degree rotation of Earth relative to distant stars (a sidereal rotation) takes about 23 hours 56 minutes 4 seconds.
content.source_5: Civil timekeeping is tied to the mean solar day rather than the sidereal day, so solar noon recurs at roughly 24-hour intervals even though the sidereal rotation is ~4 minutes shorter.
content.source_6: Earth’s axis is tilted by about 23.4 degrees relative to its orbital plane; this tilt drives seasons but does not materially change the duration of a single rotation.

answer: It takes 24 hours and causes night and day.
